items.content_html: Saturday has become my day to eat way too much food, which is not a good development. Hopefully I can sort this out before it becomes a big problem.
Today I am grateful for Spring Training and the return of Major League Baseball. ‚öæÔ∏è I watched two exposition games, which was fun and relaxing.
SwiftoDo 2.8.1 is now available in the App Store. It adds a Solarized Light and Solarized Dark themes, fixes bugs, and changes opening the URL menu from a long press to a slide gesture.
I would never replace my AirPods with the new ones rumored today just to upgrade them, but if I broke or lost mine, I would buy them in a second.
Alto‚Äôs Odyssey has, predictably, lowered my productivity the past two days. Still, there are two updates to SwiftoDo in the hopper. The first will be released tomorrow.

I learned of a service that makes RSS feeds out of Twitter users‚Äô tweets: TwitRSS.me. I added some noteworthy users to my feeds in Reeder, so I don‚Äôt miss their tweets, but also don‚Äôt have to go to Twitter to get them. Does anyone know what the best Twitter/RSS service is?
The weather was unusually warm today. I spent some of my lunch break walking outside.
Current mood.
I‚Äôm coding a nice new feature for SwiftoDo tonight. Hopefully it will be done tomorrow or Thursday, and I can get it in users hands by next weekend. Line 8 in the screenshot is new.
üöÄ I finally installed Rocket on my Mac. It‚Äôs a lot nicer to use than Character Viewer (Control+Command+Space) to drop emoji into text boxes.
üéô This week‚Äôs episode had me Googling for ‚Äòlongest episode of ‚ÄúThe Talk Show‚Äù with John Gruber ever‚Äô.
Blog post: A/B/C testing: ‚ÄúAugust and Everything After‚Äù, in 24-bit, 96kHz FLAC vs. 16-bit, 44.1kHz ALAC vs. 256 kbps AAC
üéµ If you like The Weakerthans as much as I do, you will find this interview with their singer, John K. Samson, fascinating.
We had an enormous house party today. It was a lot of fun, but boy are we wiped out! üéà

üé¨ I saw ‚ÄúThor: Ragnarok‚Äù today and thoroughly enjoyed it. The ‚ÄúThor‚Äù and ‚ÄúCaptain America‚Äù series started off a little weak but ended up much stronger than the ‚ÄúIron Man‚Äù series, which had the opposite trajectory. It‚Äôs upsetting that they never made a ‚ÄúBlack Widow‚Äù movie series.

Another SwiftoDo update will come at the end of next week, as long as I can get the timing right with App Store review. I cannot promise weekly updates forever, but right now I am trying to release the best version possible to my users, as soon as possible.

SwiftoDo 2.8.0 is now available in the App Store. It adds a picker to make adding recurrence pattern tags (for daily, weekly, monthly, etc.) to tasks easier. It also lets you drop tasks onto the task list from other apps (iPad only).

I am listening to music from my MacBook Pro today, via the Oppo HA-2SE. One benefit is that it charges through its micro USB input, so playtime is unlimited. iTunes is slower and buggier than the iOS Music app, though.

Adding my Nest thermostat to HomeKit via HomeBridge has made my life a little better. I do have a suggestion for Apple, though: ‚ÄúHey Siri, set thermostat to 70¬∫ F and let no one in my family change it, ever, for any reason.‚Äù Maybe I don‚Äôt need a smart thermostat after all.

I downloaded Visual Studio Code on my Windows work machine today. I don‚Äôt see how it will be better than Sublime Text for me however. I mostly need speed and some extensibility, and don‚Äôt need to compile or debug so much.
My wife baked a delicious Valentine‚Äôs Day treat. ‚ù§Ô∏èüòÑ
Blog post: My Slide into Audiophile Territory, Part 1

Tonight I set up HomeBridge on an otherwise unused Raspberry Pi to control my Nest thermostat via Siri and HomeKit. The hardest part for me was getting it set up as a service, because I hadn‚Äôt used systemd before. I blame/thank FreeBSD for that!
If Apple really is slowing down and fixing bugs, rather than adding features, I wish they would work more on Xcode 9, which is still a mess for me for Swift development.
I‚Äôm coding a user-requested feature this evening. I started really late after a 2-hour trip to Wegmans. I stayed up to do a particularly satisfying refactor.
